scopeRules.label: Route or scheme specific
scopeRules.description: Official datasets that directly identify an asylum route, refugee resettlement scheme, refugee family route, or humanitarian route.

scopeRules.label: Local route-relevant
scopeRules.description: Council statements, FOIs, planning records, or local documents that explicitly refer to asylum hotels, refugee resettlement, Afghan arrivals, Ukraine arrivals, or related local response.

scopeRules.label: Context only
scopeRules.description: General council finance, procurement, or supplier data kept as research context and never merged into public asylum or refugee charts unless a row is explicitly tied to a route or scheme.

routeFamilies.label: Small boat arrivals
routeFamilies.localBreakdown: Not publicly broken down by local authority
routeFamilies.note: Use small boat or illegal entry route language for the route. Public local asylum-support data does not usually say which supported people arrived this way.

routeFamilies.label: Asylum seekers receiving support
routeFamilies.localBreakdown: Published by local authority and region
routeFamilies.note: Best local asylum pressure series, but not a route split. It includes people on support regardless of how they arrived.

routeFamilies.label: Afghan Resettlement Programme
routeFamilies.localBreakdown: Published locally as a combined Afghan programme
routeFamilies.note: Public local data usually combines Afghan pathways at programme level rather than separating ARAP and ACRS in every table.

routeFamilies.label: UK Resettlement Scheme, Mandate, and Community Sponsorship
routeFamilies.localBreakdown: Not consistently separated in the latest local immigration-group tables
routeFamilies.note: Public resettlement outputs often group UKRS and Mandate together, with community sponsorship included within that total.

routeFamilies.label: Refugee Family Reunion
routeFamilies.note: This is a family route connected to people who already have refugee status or humanitarian protection in the UK.

routeFamilies.label: Homes for Ukraine
routeFamilies.localBreakdown: Published by local authority and region
routeFamilies.note: Useful local route comparison layer but should never be merged into asylum accommodation totals.

facts.label: Small boat arrivals
facts.detail: Official count of people detected arriving by small boat.

facts.label: People in asylum hotels
facts.detail: Asylum support accommodation figure, not a refugee-scheme total.

facts.label: Resettled refugees
facts.detail: Official resettlement total. Most were through the Afghan Resettlement Programme.

facts.label: Afghan share of resettlement
facts.detail: The Afghan programme dominated current refugee resettlement volumes.

facts.label: Refugee Family Reunion visas
facts.detail: Rounded official out-of-country grants for the refugee family reunion route.

facts.label: Safe and legal humanitarian grants
facts.detail: Mainly driven by the Ukraine Permission Extension route, so keep humanitarian routes separate from refugee resettlement.

hotelFacts.label: Hotels in use
hotelFacts.detail: Official count reported to the Home Affairs Committee.

hotelFacts.label: People in asylum hotels
hotelFacts.detail: Asylum support accommodation figure, not a refugee-scheme total.

hotelFacts.label: Daily hotel cost
hotelFacts.detail: Home Office stated average daily hotel cost.

hotelFacts.label: Hotel cost share
hotelFacts.detail: Hotels housed 35% of those in asylum accommodation but drove most accommodation cost.

contractSignals.title: Do not mix small boats with refugee schemes
contractSignals.body: Small boat arrivals are an irregular arrival route into the asylum system. They are not a refugee resettlement scheme and should not be counted alongside Afghan or UK resettlement schemes.

contractSignals.title: Do not mix refugee schemes with Ukraine routes
contractSignals.body: Homes for Ukraine and Ukraine Permission Extension are humanitarian routes. They belong in route comparison, but not in a refugee-resettlement chart without clear labeling.

contractSignals.title: Keep local support pressure separate from arrival route
contractSignals.body: Local asylum-support figures show where pressure sits, but they usually do not tell you whether supported people arrived by small boat or another route.

localEvidence.title: Bell Hotel and Phoenix Hotel publicly named
localEvidence.detail: Strong named current-site evidence for the asylum accommodation estate.

localEvidence.title: Cedar Court Hotel confirmed for contingency asylum accommodation
localEvidence.detail: Direct local evidence of a current asylum hotel and local political response.

localEvidence.title: Local housing fund linked to Afghan and Ukraine arrivals
localEvidence.detail: Useful example of a local public source explicitly tying housing activity to refugee and humanitarian schemes.

localEvidence.title: Three asylum hotels confirmed but unnamed
localEvidence.detail: Useful secrecy-gap evidence because hotel presence is acknowledged without a public site list.

excludedContext.title: Whole-council spending ledgers
excludedContext.detail: General council transaction data is not shown on protection-route charts unless rows can be explicitly linked to asylum accommodation, refugee resettlement, Ukraine response, or related local service pressure.

excludedContext.title: Generic council procurement notices
excludedContext.detail: Contracts Finder notices for a council are context only until the notice text or supplier clearly ties the contract to asylum accommodation, refugee resettlement housing, or another specific route.

excludedContext.title: Whole-body budgets
excludedContext.detail: Council budget totals can explain local capacity but they are not route-specific spend and should never be presented as if they were.

inclusionTests: Include publicly if the source explicitly identifies an asylum route, refugee scheme, family route, or humanitarian route.
Keep small boat arrivals separate from refugee resettlement schemes and from Ukraine humanitarian routes.
Treat local hotel statements, resettlement housing statements, FOIs, and planning records as local route-relevant evidence, not as national totals.
Keep general council finance and procurement as background context unless a row can be attributed to a specific route or scheme.
